If `z` is a non-real complex root of a real polynomial,
then `p` is divisible by a quadratic polynomial.

type:
∀ (p : Polynomial ℝ) {z : ℂ},
  (Polynomial.aeval z) p = 0 →
    z.im ≠ 0 → Polynomial.X ^ 2 - Polynomial.C (2 * z.re) * Polynomial.X + Polynomial.C (‖z‖ ^ 2) ∣ p
name: Polynomial.quadratic_dvd_of_aeval_eq_zero_im_ne_zero
docString:
If `z` is a non-real complex root of a real polynomial,
then `p` is divisible by a quadratic polynomial.

Every non-constant complex polynomial has at least one complex root.

type: ∀ {f : Polynomial ℂ}, 0 < f.degree → ∃ z, f.IsRoot z
name: Complex.exists_root
docString: Every non-constant complex polynomial has at least one complex root.

The theorem `Polynomial.roots_C` states that for any commutative ring `R` that is also an integral domain, and any element `x` from `R`, the roots of the constant polynomial `C x` (i.e., a polynomial that has the same value `x` at every point) are an empty set. In other words, a constant polynomial has no roots.

type: ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] (x : R), (Polynomial.C x).roots = 0
name: Polynomial.roots_C
docString: The theorem `Polynomial.roots_C` states that for any commutative ring `R` that is also an integral domain, and any element `x` from `R`, the roots of the constant polynomial `C x` (i.e., a polynomial that has the same value `x` at every point) are an empty set. In other words, a constant polynomial has no roots.

**Fundamental theorem of algebra**: every non constant complex polynomial
has a root

type: ∀ {f : Polynomial ℂ}, 0 < f.degree → ∃ z, f.IsRoot z
name: Complex.exists_root
docString:
**Fundamental theorem of algebra**: every non constant complex polynomial
has a root

If `p` is a separable polynomial over an integral domain `R`, then `p` has no repeated roots.

type: ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] {p : Polynomial R}, p.Separable → p.roots.Nodup
name: Polynomial.nodup_roots
docString: If `p` is a separable polynomial over an integral domain `R`, then `p` has no repeated roots.

This theorem states that for any commutative ring `R` which is also an integral domain, and for any non-zero polynomial `p` over `R`, the set of roots of `p` (i.e., the set of elements `x` in `R` such that `p` evaluated at `x` equals 0) is finite. In other words, a non-zero polynomial over an integral domain has only finitely many roots.

type: ∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] {p : Polynomial R}, p ≠ 0 → {x | p.IsRoot x}.Finite
name: Polynomial.finite_setOf_isRoot
docString: This theorem states that for any commutative ring `R` which is also an integral domain, and for any non-zero polynomial `p` over `R`, the set of roots of `p` (i.e., the set of elements `x` in `R` such that `p` evaluated at `x` equals 0) is finite. In other words, a non-zero polynomial over an integral domain has only finitely many roots.

The number of roots of a real polynomial `p` is at most the number of roots of its derivative
that are not roots of `p` plus one.

type: ∀ (p : Polynomial ℝ), p.roots.toFinset.card ≤ ((Polynomial.derivative p).roots.toFinset \ p.roots.toFinset).card + 1
name: Polynomial.card_roots_toFinset_le_card_roots_derivative_diff_roots_succ
docString:
The number of roots of a real polynomial `p` is at most the number of roots of its derivative
that are not roots of `p` plus one.

If `p : R[X]` is a nonzero polynomial with root `z`, `integralNormalization p` is
a monic polynomial with root `leadingCoeff f * z`.

Moreover, `integralNormalization 0 = 0`.

type: {R : Type u} → [inst : Semiring R] → Polynomial R → Polynomial R
name: Polynomial.integralNormalization
docString:
If `p : R[X]` is a nonzero polynomial with root `z`, `integralNormalization p` is
a monic polynomial with root `leadingCoeff f * z`.

Moreover, `integralNormalization 0 = 0`.

A non-constant polynomial has non-zero separable degree.

type: ∀ {F : Type u} [inst : Field F] (f : Polynomial F), f.natDegree ≠ 0 → f.natSepDegree ≠ 0
name: Polynomial.natSepDegree_ne_zero
docString: A non-constant polynomial has non-zero separable degree.

The multiplicity of `a` as root of a nonzero polynomial `p` is at least `n` iff
`(X - a) ^ n` divides `p`.

type:
∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] {p : Polynomial R},
  p ≠ 0 → ∀ {a : R} {n : ℕ}, n ≤ Polynomial.rootMultiplicity a p ↔ (Polynomial.X - Polynomial.C a) ^ n ∣ p
name: Polynomial.le_rootMultiplicity_iff
docString:
The multiplicity of `a` as root of a nonzero polynomial `p` is at least `n` iff
`(X - a) ^ n` divides `p`.

A polynomial has non-zero separable degree if and only if it is non-constant.

type: ∀ {F : Type u} [inst : Field F] (f : Polynomial F), f.natSepDegree ≠ 0 ↔ f.natDegree ≠ 0
name: Polynomial.natSepDegree_ne_zero_iff
docString: A polynomial has non-zero separable degree if and only if it is non-constant.

A monic polynomial `p` that has as many roots as its degree
can be written `p = ∏(X - a)`, for `a` in `p.roots`.

type:
∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] {p : Polynomial R},
  p.Monic → p.roots.card = p.natDegree → (Multiset.map (fun a => Polynomial.X - Polynomial.C a) p.roots).prod = p
name: Polynomial.prod_multiset_X_sub_C_of_monic_of_roots_card_eq
docString:
A monic polynomial `p` that has as many roots as its degree
can be written `p = ∏(X - a)`, for `a` in `p.roots`.

A polynomial `p` that has as many roots as its degree
can be written `p = p.leadingCoeff * ∏(X - a)`, for `a` in `p.roots`.

type:
∀ {R : Type u} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] {p : Polynomial R},
  p.roots.card = p.natDegree →
    Polynomial.C p.leadingCoeff * (Multiset.map (fun a => Polynomial.X - Polynomial.C a) p.roots).prod = p
name: Polynomial.C_leadingCoeff_mul_prod_multiset_X_sub_C
docString:
A polynomial `p` that has as many roots as its degree
can be written `p = p.leadingCoeff * ∏(X - a)`, for `a` in `p.roots`.

The `p`-adic value of an integer `z ≠ 0` is the multiplicity of `p` in `z`.

type: ∀ {p : ℕ} {z : ℤ}, p ≠ 1 → z ≠ 0 → padicValRat p ↑z = ↑(multiplicity (↑p) z)
name: padicValRat.of_int_multiplicity
docString: The `p`-adic value of an integer `z ≠ 0` is the multiplicity of `p` in `z`.

`roots p` noncomputably gives a multiset containing all the roots of `p`,
including their multiplicities.

type: {R : Type u} → [inst : CommRing R] → [inst_1 : IsDomain R] → Polynomial R → Multiset R
name: Polynomial.roots
docString:
`roots p` noncomputably gives a multiset containing all the roots of `p`,
including their multiplicities.

If `k` is algebraically closed, then every nonconstant polynomial has a root.


[Stacks Tag 09GR](https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/09GR) ((4) ⟹ (3))

type: ∀ {k : Type u} [inst : Field k] [inst_1 : IsAlgClosed k] (p : Polynomial k), p.degree ≠ 0 → ∃ x, p.IsRoot x
name: IsAlgClosed.exists_root
docString:
If `k` is algebraically closed, then every nonconstant polynomial has a root.


[Stacks Tag 09GR](https://stacks.math.columbia.edu/tag/09GR) ((4) ⟹ (3))

A constant polynomial has zero separable degree.

type: ∀ {F : Type u} [inst : Field F] (f : Polynomial F), f.natDegree = 0 → f.natSepDegree = 0
name: Polynomial.natSepDegree_eq_zero
docString: A constant polynomial has zero separable degree.

Over an integral domain, the Pochhammer polynomial of degree `n` has roots *only* at
`0`, `-1`, ..., `-(n - 1)`.

type:
∀ {R : Type u} [inst : Ring R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] (n : ℕ) (r : R),
  Polynomial.eval r (ascPochhammer R n) = 0 ↔ ∃ k < n, ↑k = -r
name: ascPochhammer_eval_eq_zero_iff
docString:
Over an integral domain, the Pochhammer polynomial of degree `n` has roots *only* at
`0`, `-1`, ..., `-(n - 1)`.

This technical lemma asserts the existence of a polynomial `p` in an ideal `P ⊂ R[x]`
that is non-zero in the quotient `R / (P ∩ R) [x]`.  The assumptions are equivalent to
`P ≠ 0` and `P ∩ R = (0)`.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] {P : Ideal (Polynomial R)},
  P ≠ ⊥ →
    (∀ (x : R), Polynomial.C x ∈ P → x = 0) →
      ∃ p ∈ P, Polynomial.map (Ideal.Quotient.mk (Ideal.comap Polynomial.C P)) p ≠ 0
name: Ideal.exists_nonzero_mem_of_ne_bot
docString:
This technical lemma asserts the existence of a polynomial `p` in an ideal `P ⊂ R[x]`
that is non-zero in the quotient `R / (P ∩ R) [x]`.  The assumptions are equivalent to
`P ≠ 0` and `P ∩ R = (0)`.

`ζ - 1` is prime if `ζ` is a primitive `p`-th root of unity.

type:
∀ {p : ℕ+} {K : Type u} [inst : Field K] {ζ : K} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime ↑p)] [inst_1 : CharZero K]
  [h : IsCyclotomicExtension {p} ℚ K] (hζ : IsPrimitiveRoot ζ ↑p), Prime (hζ.toInteger - 1)
name: IsPrimitiveRoot.zeta_sub_one_prime'
docString: `ζ - 1` is prime if `ζ` is a primitive `p`-th root of unity.

If `R` is of characteristic `p` and `¬p ∣ m`, then `ζ` is a root of `cyclotomic (p ^ k * m) R`
if and only if it is a primitive `m`-th root of unity.

type:
∀ {m k p : ℕ} {R : Type u_1} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)] [hchar : CharP R p]
  {μ : R} [inst_2 : NeZero ↑m], (Polynomial.cyclotomic (p ^ k * m) R).IsRoot μ ↔ IsPrimitiveRoot μ m
name: Polynomial.isRoot_cyclotomic_prime_pow_mul_iff_of_charP
docString:
If `R` is of characteristic `p` and `¬p ∣ m`, then `ζ` is a root of `cyclotomic (p ^ k * m) R`
if and only if it is a primitive `m`-th root of unity.

In a `p`-th cyclotomic extension of `ℚ `, we have that `ζ` is not congruent to an
integer modulo `p` if `p ≠ 2`.

type:
∀ {p : ℕ+} {K : Type u} [inst : Field K] {ζ : K} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime ↑p)] [inst_1 : CharZero K]
  [hcycl : IsCyclotomicExtension {p} ℚ K] (hζ : IsPrimitiveRoot ζ ↑p), p ≠ 2 → ¬∃ n, ↑↑p ∣ hζ.toInteger - ↑n
name: IsPrimitiveRoot.not_exists_int_prime_dvd_sub_of_prime_ne_two'
docString:
In a `p`-th cyclotomic extension of `ℚ `, we have that `ζ` is not congruent to an
integer modulo `p` if `p ≠ 2`.

`ζ - 1` is prime if `ζ` is a primitive `p ^ (k + 1)`-th root of unity.

type:
∀ {p : ℕ+} {k : ℕ} {K : Type u} [inst : Field K] {ζ : K} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime ↑p)] [inst_1 : CharZero K]
  [inst_2 : IsCyclotomicExtension {p ^ (k + 1)} ℚ K] (hζ : IsPrimitiveRoot ζ ↑(p ^ (k + 1))), Prime (hζ.toInteger - 1)
name: IsPrimitiveRoot.zeta_sub_one_prime
docString: `ζ - 1` is prime if `ζ` is a primitive `p ^ (k + 1)`-th root of unity.

A polynomial has zero separable degree if and only if it is constant.

type: ∀ {F : Type u} [inst : Field F] (f : Polynomial F), f.natSepDegree = 0 ↔ f.natDegree = 0
name: Polynomial.natSepDegree_eq_zero_iff
docString: A polynomial has zero separable degree if and only if it is constant.
